content:
Hey all!

Meeting in ~30 minutes, though I don't believe there's anything firmly on the agenda for this week -- so may be a short meeting.
@T-release meeting!
@cuviper do you want to say/discuss anything about blog post?
ref: https://hackmd.io/l1WclNebStuO3l735zj4XA
I've filled it out more
still not sure about going in depth on disjoint captures... but I saw a note in the edition stream that they may want dedicated blog posts?
I think dedicated blog posts might happen but we shouldn't depend on it
well the edition guide also has details
it's complicated enough to me that we'll either want a fairly large section, or defer elsewhere
Yeah, I think... maybe we actually cut down the table of contents a little (instead with a "See more in the edition guide") and then put the closure capture changes as a category in its own right
would you be interested in writing that section? :)
though largely, IMO, with a message not about the details but rather "As with NLL and struct field reordering, we're continuing to make writing Rust code easier" as a sort of headline there.
I don't think I'll have the bandwidth to do it well
But I think even as-is the post is pretty good, so we need not necessarily iterate further

simulacrum said:

though largely, IMO, with a message not about the details but rather "As with NLL and struct field reordering, we're continuing to make writing Rust code easier" as a sort of headline there.

yeah, I'd put it in that terms along with an example or two about code that was rejected before and now is accepted

It might even be advantageous to just .... drop most of the 2021 edition section, in favor of focusing in on the highlight feature (at least IMO), which is the closure changes, and then say "For more details on the rest of the changes in the edition, please read the edition guide" -- using our existing trailing paragraph to end out, basically
But I also don't want to put a bunch of work on @cuviper necessarily
hmm, I like having the list at hand as a direct teaser
I think the list feels big and long and is short of disbalanced in practice (i.e. the bullets don't have "equal weight")
in the sense that most items on there shouldn't change how users write rust, etc.
I'll give a shot at a disjoint captures section, then we can decide what to keep
Ok, thanks!
if I can keep it brief, maybe it will be fine to have both that and the list
I think stealing from edition guide / stabilization / other material is totally fine, too.
I would prefer to have more on closures and less of a list, fwiw
but we can see how it looks
ok
(Maybe even just bullets -> sentence with commas would help me though)
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
ok
I haven't gotten a chance to look through regressions (https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/milestone/85) recently, but I think from passive listening things are moving along
I'm probably going to try to eke out time before monday to do that and ping folks if needed
@Pietro Albini are we still good for you to run release this cycle (I think it's your turn? I could easily be wrong though)
yes
ok
it's my turn and I'll be able to run this cycle
@triagebot end-meeting I think?

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
alright, let's call it here then -- thanks everyone! :wave:
:wave:
